prior_works.title: Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference (2nd ed.)
prior_works.role: Foundational theory and calculus of interventions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the SCM semantics, d-separation machinery, twin-network construction, and the three rules of do-calculus that the paper generalizes into a counterfactual (ctf-) calculus and uses as the semantic basis for AMNs.

prior_works.title: Single World Intervention Graphs (SWIGs): A Unification of the Counterfactual and Graphical Approaches to Causality
prior_works.authors: Thomas S. Richardson, James M. Robins
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces a graphical formalism to encode counterfactual variables and read independences via graphical separation, directly inspiring the paper’s multi-world graphical construction and its use of separation to read counterfactual independences.

prior_works.title: Counterfactuals and Policy Analysis: Empirical Methods for Structural Models
prior_works.role: Early formalization of counterfactual queries and multi-world constructions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Develops twin-network style constructions and linear-programming approaches for counterfactuals, establishing the multi-world perspective that AMNs systematize and render analyzable via d-separation.

prior_works.title: Identifiability of Path-Specific Effects
prior_works.authors: N. Avin, Ilya Shpitser, Judea Pearl
prior_works.role: Counterfactual graph construction and cross-world reasoning
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Uses counterfactual graphs to capture cross-world variables and their dependencies for path-specific effects, a key antecedent to the paper’s Ancestral Multi-world Networks for reading cross-world independences.

prior_works.title: Identification of Counterfactuals
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides complete procedures for identifying counterfactual expressions from causal diagrams, which the ctf-calculus abstracts into general transformation rules licensed by graphical constraints.

prior_works.title: Pearl’s Calculus of Interventions is Complete
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes completeness of the do-calculus for interventional distributions, a result the paper explicitly generalizes by proposing a calculus for counterfactuals with analogous soundness/completeness aims.

prior_works.title: An Axiomatic Characterization of Causal Counterfactuals
prior_works.role: Axioms for counterfactual independence in SCMs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides axioms governing counterfactual relations implied by structural equations, grounding the independence constraints that AMNs encode and that underwrite the ctf-calculus rules.

synthesis_narrative: Correa and Bareinboim’s core advances—Ancestral Multi-world Networks (AMNs) and a counterfactual calculus—sit squarely on the structural causal model (SCM) paradigm and its graphical-algebraic tools. Pearl’s Causality codified SCM semantics, d-separation, and the do-calculus, establishing how graphical constraints license algebraic transformations of interventional queries; the present work extends this logic from interventions to counterfactuals. Early counterfactual formalisms by Balke and Pearl introduced twin-network, multi-world constructions and optimization-based inference for counterfactuals, seeding the idea that cross-world structure can be made explicit and exploited. Richardson and Robins’ SWIGs later provided a principled graphical representation for counterfactual variables within a single-world indexing scheme, enabling separation-based reading of counterfactual independences; AMNs generalize this line by assembling multi-world, ancestrally closed networks in which d-separation is sound and complete for counterfactual independences. On the identification side, Shpitser and Pearl developed complete algorithms for counterfactual identification, demonstrating that graphical structure suffices to reduce complex counterfactuals to estimands—an algorithmic capability the new ctf-calculus abstracts into three general transformation rules. The completeness perspective is reinforced by Huang and Valtorta’s proof that do-calculus is complete for interventional identification, which motivates and frames the paper’s counterpart completeness claim for counterfactual transformations. Finally, Galles and Pearl’s axiomatic characterization of counterfactuals provides the logical underpinnings for cross-world independences that AMNs encode graphically. Together, these works directly scaffold the paper’s contribution: a sound-and-complete d-separation criterion for counterfactual independences and a calculus that generalizes do-calculus to the counterfactual domain.
